Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, June 26, 1922

div1.p: Hanson discusses yellow fever cases in Peru.

div1.head: Letter to My dear Doctor Carter, June 26, 1922
div1.opener:
DIRECCION DE LA CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN EL PERU
----
OFICINA CENTRAL
----
BOOK
Hanson
June 26, 1922.
Dr. H.R. Carter,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have just received your letter of June 3,
written after you got out of the Hospita, I am sorry that you are
not much improved, however let us hope that the brace which Dr. Baer
is fixing up for you will give you the relief expected.

Now in regard to the statistics which you ask for I judge
the enclosed sheet will give you most of the things you want. It
was gooten up by Burga to serve as a resume (statistical) of the
campaign, and in as much as there were many asking for such data
we had them printed in this form. Unfortunately some data was not
included as it should have been and no reference was made to the
campaign in Piura. He got this up as the work done under the auspices
of the Rockefeller Foundation. The number of cases given are simply
those of which there is a complete medical history, and does not
represent the total seen and diagnoses as yellow fever by the differ-
ent members of the Medical staff of the campaign. The total seen
and diagnosed was 1063. Also you will note that under the heading
of Pueblos infectadas, 53 of them we have not included those of
the campaigns of the previous years. The work given for the Depart-
ment of Piura simply refers to what we did this year as a fial check
on the north. We went up there to check on the Stegomyia conditions
in Catacaos and Paita, and also made a general fish distribution,
both as propaganda and to hold down the breeding.

Im am very much surpirsed to hear that you had received no
letters since the 21st of February. I shall look up my files and
the copies of letters which I have sent you since that time. It is
probable that I quit writing you during the month of March since at
that time I did not expect to stay on as long as I have. At that
time I had no intention of accepting the position of Director of
Public Health, and it was not until after the 15th of March that I
did so. However from some of the remarks which you have made commen-
ting on my taking the position I gained the impression that you
must have received letters of a later date than that of February 21.

We have closed all our yellow fever work. I am now only
waiting for Guldstrand to present me the final statement of accounts.
We closed the Lima Office on the 15th of this month. Most of our
materials have been sold, and the only remaining thing is to write
the report. This however is a big job and will take some time, and
probably will have to be done after I leave Peru. I shall only en-
deavor to get them a preliminary report, a sort of an official good-
bye.

They say that they do not want me to leave, and that I am
needed here etc., so to make my getaway a little easier I am sub-
mitting a proposition to them to the effect that if they will pass
the necessary legislation and procure the funds needed I will con-
sider coming back for two or three years to organize the Health
Department for them and to get them on a working basis. I am inclined
to think that they will not do this.

Dunn writes me that the I.H.B. is planning an extensive mal-
aria campaign in Italy, and that the I.H.B. is looking for a Medic
to take charge of the medical end of this work. This sounds inter-

interesting to me, and I think I should like to be considered if
there is nothing else in sight, however we can discuss this when I
arrive in the U.S.A.

I shall leave here either at the end of July or a little
before, probably a little before as I need to stop for a few days
in Panama to gather up some articles which I have in storage, and
some Liberty Bonds etc. In my last letter I think I told you
that I expected to get one of the P.S.N.C. boats and go direct to
New York, but at the present it appears that there will be no P.S.N.C
boat in the month of July after the 21st, and I may arrange to go to
Panama on it.

As this was written simply to be a letter of transmittal of
the enclosed resume I shall close, but will write you again before
sailing for the states.

I have your cable and also your former letter about the money
you have on depsoit, and as it seems very highly possible that the
exchange will soon pass beyond the point of 4.25 I am waiting a bit
before converting. Today it is 4.10.
With all good wishes from the whole family, I am
